No, so I so it also combines my artwork when I'm doing, say, beach art.
I started that in 2010 with the residents I had on Coney Beach, which is sort of a it's probably not the most spiritual place you'd think of.
But I decided to take up the challenge of making Coney Beach, which is right by the fairground, right by Treco Bay, very, very public beach.
And there's a lot of litter that tends to be like a bit of donkey droppings and donkey droppings and everything in the summer.
And I decided to have a month to a month's residency there and visit the beach every single day, do a kind of beach clean and take personal responsibility for the environment,
taking care of the environment and creating a kind of spiritual connection, sacred connection with that space to see if I could change the energy of what was already there.
Not that there was anything wrong with the energy there, but I mean just that whole sort of environmental and just just being in nature.
Because usually I would go somewhere quite remote, such as Scare and make where I've got my own sort of stone circle and I go and it's very much conducive to some way you would more like liken to a sacred space.
Whereas Coney Beach is not in public view, so it's kind of for me it was a bit of a coming out of not.
What was the public reaction to finding you doing this?
Because there you were accessible, aren't you?
Yeah, yeah, well, that's the whole point is because is to be to be visible, picking up rubbish, inviting people to come along to pick up rubbish, but also to invite people to make artwork on the beach.
And you know, and then it wasn't obviously a spiritual act.
It was more because sort of the intention was there that that's what I was doing.
I was I was connecting with that environment to improve the environment and to connect with people that were there.
But in actual fact, the last day that I was there, it was on 31st of August.
There is a crowds come to see the firework display because it's seaside town.
And in fact, I started to make lanterns and that was the first time it would probably be maybe a little bit more spiritual in looking.
And there's big crowds of people came up that teenagers not not really anybody asked for 15, 16 year olds that were hanging around with nothing to do other than wait for the fireworks to happen.
And so they came around and they were kind of getting involved and and one person said, oh, my gosh, I can't believe we're on Coney Beach.
It's totally different. It's like being in another place.
So for me, it worked. It's transformative arts, isn't it?
Yes, it's the power of it, which brings us full circle, because that's certainly one of the ways in which I like to think of of carnival arts is it's that whole the world turned upside down.
Even if you know, yes, nine tenths of it is, as you pointed out, at the carnival camp.
But for one day in the year, you know, you've got you have the Lord of Mist rule gives his or her powers to us all to to transgress and to what can I say?
You know, well, just turn the normal everyday order upside down.
Absolutely. I think it does.
I think, you know, it's it's not about people being trained or people being professionals or people being having to be a certain type of person to be involved.
It does give everybody a chance.
It's one of the few art forms which I feel is genuinely accessible.
It is very inclusive.
And it even includes people who don't want to make the art.
I mean, it's like this year we were at Fitz Allen and then there were some boys who were brought there as part of family groups by their mums and they played football outside and then they perhaps come in and have a drink or whatever.
And that's fine, too.
There's no right or wrong with carnival.
I find it's not prescriptive, is it?
Nobody's going, you have to do the following.
No, there's only one road to follow.
And I think that transformative thing is very evident because you can have people that's coming in that are very shy, very introvert or very they don't want to be sent to attention, but they get caught up in the whole energy.
And as they see their friends or their groups transformed, then it sort of it brings them out of themselves and it puts them into a place where they can experiment and they can try something out that they wouldn't normally do.
Absolutely.
And I think the duration of the camp, because it lasts three weeks, people could come in and be quite sort of objective about it and stand back.
But I think by the time it finishes, you can't help but get involved and even if they thought they wouldn't, I think it just it really brings people out, which is a great sort of self empowering tool that happens quite naturally without forcing people to be creative or to be to be to be part of something.
So pleased that this interview took place.
I thank you for your eloquence.
